dt: {bc}a {d_link|substantive|substantive:1} word, phrase, or clause whose denotation is referred to by a pronoun that typically follows the substantive (such as {it}John{/it} in "Mary saw John and called to him")
{bc}a word or phrase replaced by a substitute

dt.t: events that were {wi}antecedents{/wi} of the war

dt: {bc}the significant events, conditions, and traits of one's earlier life
{bc}a model or stimulus for later developments

dt.t: The sackbut was the {wi}antecedent{/wi} of the trombone.
He was proud of his Scottish {wi}antecedents{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the conditional element in a proposition (such as {it}if A{/it} in "if A, then B")
{bc}the first term of a mathematical ratio

et: Middle English, from Medieval Latin & Latin; Medieval Latin {it}antecedent-, antecedens{/it}, from Latin, what precedes, from neuter of {it}antecedent-, antecedens{/it}, present participle of {it}antecedere{/it} to go before, from {it}ante-{/it} + {it}cedere{/it} to go
shortdef: a substantive word, phrase, or clause whose denotation is referred to by a pronoun that typically follows the substantive (such as John in "Mary saw John and called to him"); broadly : a word or phrase replaced by a substitute
a preceding event, condition, or cause
the significant events, conditions, and traits of one's earlier life

pt: {sc}preceding{/sc} {sc}antecedent{/sc} {sc}foregoing{/sc} {sc}previous{/sc} {sc}prior{/sc} {sc}former{/sc} {sc}anterior{/sc} mean being before. {sc}preceding{/sc} usually implies being immediately before in time or in place.
{sc}antecedent{/sc} applies to order in time and may suggest a causal relation.
{sc}previous{/sc} and {sc}prior{/sc} imply existing or occurring earlier, but {sc}prior{/sc} often adds an implication of greater importance.
{sc}former{/sc} implies always a definite comparison or contrast with something that is latter.
{sc}anterior{/sc} applies to position before or ahead of usually in space, sometimes in time or order.
